abstracts.cdata!:
For the Third Education Project of
            Colombia some components of the program fared better than
            others.   Common facilities centers program was off to a
            good start.  The Rural Development Centers were striving to
            regain its directions after going through drastic changes.
            The Las Gaviotas Rural Development Services Center benefited
            in terms of its physical plant, primary school and related
            facilities. Other components of the project did not do as
            well.  Completion of the project required 8.75 years when it
            was estimated to only take 4 years.  Delays in project
            implementation were caused by: new laws enacted by a new
            government, fund shortages and poor project management. The
            Bank neglected to predict how the project would be perceived
            by a new government, which took power just eight months
            after the project took effect.  The project design should
            have been more flexible so if future changes were necessary
            that could be made without drastic modification.
            Construction and equipment costs were high for both common
            facilities centers program and rural development centers.
            This was a result of inflationary increases during
            implementation which took almost nine years.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project consists of (a) construction
            and equipping of 24 common facilities centers; (b)
            construction and equipping of 13 rural comprehensive
            schools; (c) a special program for the training of technical
            teachers; (d) an extension of the rural development center
            in Las Gaviotas in the Eastern Plains; (e) technical
            assistance for a sector survey and sector studies.  The 24
            common facilities centers would provide the necessary
            workshops and laboratories to enable a total of 91 existing
            secondary schools to adopt a diversified curriculum
            combining practical and academic subjects.  These schools
            are in general too small to make separate provision of such
            facilities economic.
